Prompt:
Example 1:
As Johnson worked on math problems with the other female computers, she would ask questions. She didn't want to just do the work — she wanted to know the "hows" and the "whys," and then the "why nots." By asking questions, Johnson began to stand out.
Women were not allowed to attend meetings with the male engineers and scientists. Johnson wanted to go to these meetings to learn more about the projects, so she went. She became known for her training in geometry and began to work with teams made up of men. Eventually, she was recognized as a leader, and the men increasingly relied on her to have the answers they needed.
In 1958, NACA officially became NASA. Shortly thereafter, Johnson became part of the space team. She began calculating the flight path, or trajectory path, for the rocket to put the first American in space in 1961. That American was astronaut Alan Shepard. The engineers knew when and where they wanted Shepard's space capsule to land, but the tricky part was to calculate when and where the rocket would have to launch. Johnson figured it out!

Example 2:
When Naomi saw that Ruth loved her so much, she forgot how tired and hungry she was, and the two journeyed on together until they came to Bethlehem in Judah in the beginning of the barley harvest. There was no famine in Bethlehem. The fields were full of waving grain, and busy servants were reaping it and gathering it up to bind into sheaves. Above all were the fields of the rich man, Boaz, shining with barley and corn.
Naomi and Ruth came to the edge of the fields and watched the busy reapers. They saw that after each sheaf was bound, and each pile of corn was stacked, a little grain fell, unnoticed, to the ground. Ruth said to Naomi: "Let me go to the field and glean the ears of corn after them." And Naomi said to her, "Go, my daughter." And she went, and came and gleaned in the field after the reapers.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'prehistory' targeting the same readability level (Upper Elementary), limited to 150 words.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'prehistory' targeting the same readability level (Upper Elementary), limited to 150 words. Before humans started writing history, there was a time called prehistory. During prehistory, people lived as hunters and gatherers. They moved around looking for food like animals. They didn't have buildings or cities. Instead, they lived in simple shelters. To learn about prehistory, scientists study rocks, bones, and tools. They look for clues about how people lived long ago. These clues help us understand our past.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'prehistory' targeting the same readability level (Upper Elementary), limited to 150 words. In prehistory, people didn't write or make tools like we do today. They didn't live in houses, either. They moved around, following herds of animals to hunt and gathering plants to eat. They didn't have any kind of calendar or way to keep time. To find out about this time, scientists study things like bones, stones, and the shapes of the earth. They use these clues to figure out how people lived long ago. It's like being a detective, solving a big, old mystery!

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'prehistory' targeting the same readability level (Upper Elementary), limited to 150 words. In prehistory, people lived long before there were written records. They did not have books or computers. They did not know how to write, so they could not write down their stories or how they did things. They lived by hunting, gathering, and farming. They used tools made of stone, wood, and bone. They made shelters from the things they found in nature. They told stories and passed on knowledge by speaking to each other. They created art, like paintings on cave walls. We learn about them from the things they left behind, like tools, art, and fossils.

In prehistory, people lived without writing or buildings made of brick. They lived in caves or small homes made of mud and sticks. They hunted for food and gathered fruits and nuts. Women and men worked together, and everyone helped each other. They didn't have tools like we do now. They used stones to cut things and wood to make fires. They learned to make clothes from animal hides. They painted pictures on cave walls to tell stories. They didn't know how to write, so they used these pictures to remember important things.

Text:
Example 1:
As Johnson worked on math problems with the other female computers, she would ask questions. She didn't want to just do the work — she wanted to know the "hows" and the "whys," and then the "why nots." By asking questions, Johnson began to stand out.
Women were not allowed to attend meetings with the male engineers and scientists. Johnson wanted to go to these meetings to learn more about the projects, so she went. She became known for her training in geometry and began to work with teams made up of men. Eventually, she was recognized as a leader, and the men increasingly relied on her to have the answers they needed.
In 1958, NACA officially became NASA. Shortly thereafter, Johnson became part of the space team. She began calculating the flight path, or trajectory path, for the rocket to put the first American in space in 1961. That American was astronaut Alan Shepard. The engineers knew when and where they wanted Shepard's space capsule to land, but the tricky part was to calculate when and where the rocket would have to launch. Johnson figured it out!

Example 2:
When Naomi saw that Ruth loved her so much, she forgot how tired and hungry she was, and the two journeyed on together until they came to Bethlehem in Judah in the beginning of the barley harvest. There was no famine in Bethlehem. The fields were full of waving grain, and busy servants were reaping it and gathering it up to bind into sheaves. Above all were the fields of the rich man, Boaz, shining with barley and corn.
Naomi and Ruth came to the edge of the fields and watched the busy reapers. They saw that after each sheaf was bound, and each pile of corn was stacked, a little grain fell, unnoticed, to the ground. Ruth said to Naomi: "Let me go to the field and glean the ears of corn after them." And Naomi said to her, "Go, my daughter." And she went, and came and gleaned in the field after the reapers.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'prehistory' targeting the same readability level (Upper Elementary), limited to 150 words. Before humans began recording history, the period of time known as prehistory existed. During this time, our ancestors lived as nomads, moving from place to place in search of food and shelter. They used tools made from stone, bone, and wood to hunt animals and gather plants. They also began to create art, such as cave paintings, to tell stories and express their thoughts and feelings. Despite the challenges of prehistory, our ancestors learned to adapt and survive in a variety of environments, laying the foundation for the civilizations that would follow.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'prehistory' targeting the same readability level (Upper Elementary), limited to 150 words. Before humans, the world was full of strange creatures and plants. Many were much bigger than any today. In prehistory, scientists study these ancient times. They find bones, shells, and plants that were left behind. By studying these clues, they learn about how life was long ago.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'prehistory' targeting the same readability level (Upper Elementary), limited to 150 words. The paragraph should describe how humans lived during prehistory and what they did for food and shelter.

In the time before history, known as prehistory, humans lived in a world filled with vast forests, open plains, and mighty rivers. They were nomads, moving from place to place, following herds of animals and gathering fruits and nuts. They didn't have tools like we do today; they used stones and sticks to hunt and gather food. For shelter, they built simple homes from branches and leaves. Life was tough, but humans were strong and learned to survive in many different lands.
